sp.p: Give me leave, young gentleman, and you shall hear—Every body imagined him to be a prudent, sedate, grave person, with a moderate share of common sense;

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: And, as it was evident his beard was grey, his limbs palsied, his skin shriveled, and his sinews shrunk;

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: How, Sir Hornet!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: They naturally concluded, he had made his will, wrote his epitaph, and bespoke his coffin;

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Mercy upon me!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p:
But instead of meditating, like a pious Christian, on the four last things, a crotchet takes him in the head, he buys a three-penny fiddle, scrapes a matrimonial jigg, claps a pair of horns upon his head, and curvets thro' the town,
the sport of the mob, derided by the young, pitied by the old, and laughed at by all the world.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Heaven deliver me, what a picture! But you forget, Sir Hornet—Didn't I explain to you, that it was only a joke?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh! true—Ah, witty rogue!—well—adieu—I'll remember the joke—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ay, do—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh! for a song to the tune of "Room for Cuckolds!"

div3.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: MAY the everlasting curse of heaven consume those implements of hell—those deceitful, infernal fiends—I'll never touch, never look on cards or dice again—If I ever make another bett, may all the horrors of a ruined fortune haunt me, sleeping and waking—May I be pointed at by children, and pitied by sharpers—Distraction! MAY I be—I AM already, ruined, past redemption.

div3.stage: Enter SERVANT, and delivers a letter to Sir HARRY.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: —Um—Um—Stay, Sir (to the servant)—Damnation! Is it possible! In league with sharpers—Who brought this letter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A porter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Gone, Sir—he ran off round the corner in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You may go, Sir.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: You seem moved, Sir Harry; may I enquire the cause?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You are the cause, Sir.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: I!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Yes, you—There, read, Sir.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: —Beware of a false friend—the person who gives you this caution, would sacrifice a life to preserve you from the destruction that threatens you—Mr. Osborne is in league with Jews and sharpers, and you are a victim to his avarice and duplicity.—So, so— (seems chagrined)—Well, Sir Harry, do you give any credit to this epistle?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, you are to tell me how much, or how little, credit it deserves.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Why look you, Sir Harry, I cannot, nor I will not, enter into explanations—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir!—Cannot, nor will not, enter into explanations!

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: But I say, Sir, you shall.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Shall!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, shall.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Ay, Sir—Who is he that SHALL make me?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am he, Sir.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Friendship, honour, honesty, ought to make you—but present appearances declare you void of these.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p:
Present appearances declare you void of reason, Sir, otherwise you would remember me for one of those who are not to be terrified by a loud tongue, or an angry brow—I repeat it—I will not now enter into explanations—I have
played with you, I have staked MY money, and won YOURS—Would it have been dishonourable had you won mine? I have disposed of that money as I thought proper.—No matter whether with Jews or Christians; and, I should have supposed, your passion and suspicion would have required better proof, than the malevolent asperson of an anonymous letter, ere they ought to have incited you to a quarrel with your friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, dear Osborne—I am to blame—nothing but the severity of my late losses can plead for me—I know you to be a noble-hearted, worthy fellow, and explanations, on such an accusation, are as much beneath you to give, as me to demand—forget my silly warmth, it is my weakness.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Do you forget the cause on't, Harry, and it is forgot.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: It was madness—I am above suspicion—'tis ungenerous—'tis damnable—pray excuse—pray forgive me.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Well, well, think no more on't—only guard against suspicion for the future.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No, no—it cannot be—there is an open fortitude in his manner—a boldness that can only result from innocence.

sp.speaker: Melissa.
sp.p:
Oh, brother, I am glad I have found you—Why did you send these troublesome things to me? Why did not you take care of them for me? Trust a giddy girl indeed with a parcel of bank bills—here, here, here they are—take 'em—take 'em—they will be safe with you—I have been in a panic, ever since they were in my possession,
lest they should take wing, and fly thro' the key-hole, or some other unaccountable way—I am unused to such large sums, and don't feel happy while they are about me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: But what am I to do with them?

sp.speaker: Melissa.
sp.p: Keep them till to-morrow, and then, you know, when them too, to make it the more acceptable—there are just twenty, of one thousand each.—So, now I am easy—good bye—I am going to purchase a few knickknacks.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Well, but, sister, Melissa. She's gone—flown on the light wings of innocence and happiness—while I, depressed by .folly, feel a weight upon my heart, that hope itself cannot remove.—What is a ruined gamester?—An ideot—who begins for his amusement, who continues hoping to retrieve, and who is ruined before he can recollect himself—a wretch—deserted, solitary, forlorn—ashamed of society, yet miserable when alone—shunned by the prosperous—despised by the prudent—deservedly exposed to the poisoned shafts of insolence and envy—a byeword to the vulgar, and a jest to the fortunate—haunted by duns, preyed upon by usurers, persecuted and curst by creditors.—Inexplicable infatuation!

div3.head: SCENE

sp.speaker: Melissa.
sp.p: Mr. Turnbull, I must beg, Sir, you'll desist—

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p:
Dezist—why to be zure—I'll go and buy license out o' hand—make hay while the zun
do zhine—and don't lose the zheep for a ha'perth o'tar—what tho'—the pepper-box must ha' a lid—a bushel o'words wunt vill a basket—when the owl goes a hunting, 'tis time to light the candle.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—If you'll permit me, my dear, I think I can relieve you from this embarrassment.

sp.speaker: Melissa.
sp.p: Permit you!—I am sure if you can, you shall be cannonized, and have churches erected to your memory.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I'll talk to him in his own language—he can comprehend no other.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Well, vair Lady.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Well, Zir.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: You do zee how the nail do drive—Be you to be one at bridal?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No!—Why zo?—you'st be bridemaid.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No but I wunt.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Wunt you?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No—nor you'st not be bridegroom nother.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: How zo!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Because you've zold the skin avore you've catch'd the vox—You've reckon'd your chickens bevore they be hatch'd

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Nay, nay—stop at the dike—zure, I do knaw my own mind—an' Miss be agreed.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But Miss ben't agreed.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No!—That's a good joke—but she be tho'.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But she ben't tho'.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: But I'm zure she be.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But I'm zure she ben't.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No!—Why Miss—ben't you agreed?

sp.speaker: Melissa.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: You may gape, but the cherry won't drop—Too much mettle is dangerous in a blind horse—Misreckoning is no payment—John would a' wed, but Mary war na willing.

sp.speaker: Melissa.
sp.p: You seem surprized, Sir—I can only say, it is without reason—You have deceived yourself, in supposing such an alliance possible, and I hope your own good sense will inform you that, after this declaration, any renewal of your addresses to me, must be considered an insult.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.stage: (Stares as if he did not comprehend her for some time)
sp.p: An' zo then—the meaning of all this vine speech, I zuppose, is that you wunt ha' me?

sp.speaker: Melissa.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: "Make hay while the zun do zhine—Don't lose the sheep for a ha'p'erth of tar—A bushel of words won't vill a basket—When the owl goes a hunting, 'tis time to light the candle"—Your most obedient, gentle 'Squire—ha! ha! ha!

Zo then—It zeems I a been reckoning without my host here—Well—What tho'—zoon hot zoon cold—zoon got zoon gone—Care's no cure—Zorrow won't pay a man's debts—He wanted a zinging bird, that gave a groat for a cuckoo—an' he that loses a wife and zixpence, has lost a tester— (Enter Miss Turnbull.) Why, Barbara! what be's the matter wi'thee? Where has thee been?

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Been!—Why I a bin wildered.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: What lost!

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—an' if I had na' by good hap met wi' John, who has got direction in written hand, it were vive golden guineas to a brass varchin I'ad been kidnapp'd, an' zent to America, among the Turks.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Zerve thee right—thee must be gadding—But I a' news vor thee—the cow'as kick't down th' milk—It's all off 'tween Miss and I—

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Zure!—rabbit me an I didn't guess as much.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Ees—the nail's clench'd—Zhe and I a' zhook hands an' parted.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!—What won't yo' ha' zhe?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No—I wunt—Her may whistle, but I zhan't hear—her may beckon, but I zhan't come—Catch me an' ha' me, I'm no vool—Zo, do you zee, an' you be minded to wed, zay grace an' vall too, vor I don't like your London tricks, an' zo I'st leave it as vast as I can.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: An' when be I to be wed?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Why, I do vind Zir Hornet be come, zo, when yo zee Zir Harry, yo' may zettle't—An', d'ye hear, Barbara—Don't let me vind yo' at any o'these skittish off an' on freaks—I a' zeen too much on 'um lately—Oh, here be Sir Harry coming—An' zo I'st leave you to make love your own way—I'st not play my ace o'trumps out yet.—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: So—here's my good whimsical uncle's Nonpareil, as he calls her—his phoenix—All alone, Miss Turnbull?

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—Brother be just gone—A's vallen out wi Miss, an a's plaguily frump'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sure!

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—A zaid, too, at yo' an I be to make love—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: He did!

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—and I do knaw his tricks—a'll be in a woundy rage, an I don't do as he bids me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: What, will he be surly?

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Zurly!—a'll snarl worser than our great dog Jowler at a beggar—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: He is ill tempered then?

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Oh, a'll zulk vor a vortnight round—an' when a comes about again, a'll make a believe to romp—an' then a' lumps—an' gripes—an' pinches—till I am quite a weary on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Well you may, I think—Poor thing (aside)—and which way are we to make love?

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious! don't you knaw?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I believe I can give a guess—You, I suppose, are to hang down your head and titter.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I—hem—and look sheepish.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You gnaw your apron—I twirl my thumbs.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: He! he!—Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You say—it's a very fine day, Sir, and I answer, Yes, Ma'am, only it rains.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: He! he! he!—Ees—iveck, that be vor all the world the very moral of our country vashion—Oh! but here be zomebody coming—

div3.stage: Enter Sir HORNET, CLARA, and VANDERVELT.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why, Harry, you dog, what have you hid yourself, because you would not see me?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Dear Sir, I am exceedingly glad to see you, but it is not a quarter of an hour since I heard of your being in town; and I suppose, Sir, you will scarcely be angry at finding me in this company—

div3.stage: (Vandervelt, Sir Harry, and Miss Turnbull, walk up the stage in conversation.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Finding you in!—Zounds, what aukward cargo of rusticity has he got there?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: A young lady from Somersetshire, with a tolerable good fortune, that Sir Harry, it is thought by some, intends to marry.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Marry!—He should as soon marry the mummy of queen Semiramis.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: She has been strongly recommended to the family, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Recommended!—By whom!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: By one you are very intimate with, and who has very great influence with Sir Harry, as well as with yourself.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ay!—Who is that?—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Pardon me there, Sir Hornet.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Certainly the fellow cannot be foolish enough to admire her—but I shall soon discover that, by what, he thinks of you—harkee, Harry!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: I cannot, upon the whole, tell very well what to make of you—Are you thoroughly convinced that you are, at this instant, legally capable of making your will?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: My will, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ay—Are you of sound mind?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I believe so, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Then pray tell me, now we have you face to face, what is your opinion of Miss Turnbull?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir!—That is by no means a question proper to be answered in this company.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Pshaw!—Damn your delicacy—Make your panegyric, and I'll blush for her and you too.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir, I have no panegyric to make.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Even so.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why you impudent confounded—Have you the barefaced effrontery, with such a picture before your eyes, to—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You have applied the torture, and my own ease requires confession.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Humph—And so you—Now pray all be attentive, for Bacon's brazen head is going to utter—So you do not think Miss Turnbull a most engaging—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why you intolerable—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am concerned to see you so serious on the subject—I must acknowledge, that in this case, Sir, I have either a most perverse or stupid imagination; and cannot, for the soul of me, discover the latent wonders in the young lady, which your better sight has so distinct a view of.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am, however, exceedingly willing to try the utmost strength of my faith, to believe as much as I can, and take the rest for granted; provided you will not inflict the punishment of a wife upon my superstition.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Obliging youth! (Bows)—inflict the punishment of a wife upon your superstition—And so you think, no doubt, a wife a burthen, much too heavy for the back of so fine and pretty a town-made gentleman as yourfelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: With the addition of Miss Turnbull's accomplishments, I most undoubtedly do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: You do—humph—Pray, most civil Sir—permit me to ask—perhaps there may be some other lady, in this good company, to whom your profound penetration would give the preference.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: If such preference could, in the least make me deserving of her, I have no scruple to say there is.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Miracle of modesty!—there is.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Most assuredly—But, tho' to possess the lady you hint at, would make me blest beyond description, I have never dared to declare so much before, because I am conscious of being unworthy of such a prosusion of charms and accomplishments.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Generous diffidence!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Charms and—What the devil is all this!—Where am I—at sea, or on shore—Have I a calenture in my brain, or is this my nose!—They—they call you Sir Harry Portland, don't they Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: And your nephew, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. Hornet.
sp.p: No—that's rather dubious—Well then, Mr. Harry, or Sir Harry, or what you please—You are pretty well convinced, I suppose, that I HAVE had some slight regard for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Perfectly, Sir, and remember it with gratitude.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p:
That remains to be proved, friend—Ever since your father's death, if I don't mistake, I have been tolerably busy, a little active,
or so, in forming your mind and manners, and moulding you into a sort of being, a man might behold without blushing.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: It is impossible, Sir, I should ever forget your goodness, tho' I am happy to be reminded of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: That's a lie, I believe—However, Sir—among the rest of my cares, I was anxious to find a woman worthy of you—Nay, so solicitous was I about adjusting preliminaries, that tho' the gout had laid an embargo upon a parcel of my fingers and toes, I resolved to forego my own ease, and set sail immediately, that I might convoy you sase into the harbour of happiness.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am very sensible of the benevolence of your intentions, Sir, and only wish you had done me the honour to—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Well, I have only a word or two more to say on the subject—I have been an enthusiastic old blockhead, 'tis true, and was fool enough to think all men had eyes; however, if you have not either the complaisance, the wit, or the love, to hit upon some expedient to make your peace with Miss Turnbull, I will never see, never know, never speak to you again. And now, Sir, you will act as your great wisdom shall direct.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
Indeed, Sir, I am distressed to see you so intent upon this busines; I am exceedingly unhappy, to do the least thing to incur your displeasure—at this moment especially—I have a thousand reasons to be disatisfied with myself, and am grieved to add your anger to the lift—I would do any thing, in my power, to preserve your friendship and affection; but this is too severe a task—I cannot totally forget common sense—I cannot entirely command so delicate a passion, as that of love—A little time will discover,
whether I am ever to think of love or happiness again!—Of this, however, I am certain—I never can possess either with Miss Turnbull—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Indeed youngster! so resolute!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What a noble fortitude!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: We shall see who will first read their recantation—An insensible blind puppy—I'll be a greater torment to him, than a beadle to a beggar—a cat to a rat—or a candle to a moth—I'll singe his wings—I'll plague him worse than Moses did the Egyptians.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh, Sir Hornet! you'll soon be of another opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Never—never—never.— (Enter 'Squire behind, unperceived.) However, let him act as he will, Miss Turnbull shall have no cause to repent her coming to London.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: What! will yo' take me to zee the zights?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Who the devil bade that goose cackle?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: A curst idiot—or I have no skill in physiognomy.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: What, Barbara!—Ees—that her be—tho' no vool, neather—her do knaw better than to thatch her house wi' pancakes.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Pshaw—Miss Turnbull!

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—I be here.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Again!— (takes Clara by the hand) Give me leave, I say, dear Miss Turnbull, to—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Hey! Sir Hornet!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why!—what!—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: You don't take my turtle for Miss Turnbull, sure?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Your turtle!—I don't know what you mean by your turtle; but I take this young lady for Miss Turnbull, sure.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: You do!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes—I do.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why—what the devil—hey—why sure—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ah! ha! ha! ha! ha!—This is a good joke.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: A good joke!—Why, Madam—'Squire—Zounds—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ah! ha! ha! ha! ha!—I would not have missed this for a thousand pounds in new coined guineas.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Mr. Turnbull—Sir—Is not this your sister, Sir?—

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Zister!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: What thic!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Thic Barbara!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Zounds, yes, I tell you.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Why no, to be zure—thic be Barbara.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—the biter bit—the fleerer fleer'd—ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Thic be Barbara—

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Ees—Thic be Barbara—

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—I be Barbara.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Why, what a numskull your nephew is, Sir Hornet!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: A blind, insensible puppy!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Is he?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: But you'll torment him—you'll singe his wings—you'll plague him worse than Moses did the Egyptians—What a discovery!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh, yes—I have made more discoveries!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ay, what are they?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why the first is—You're an old fool—the next is—I am another—and the third is, that we are not the only two fools in company.

div3.stage: Manent 'SQUIRE and Miss TURNBULL. (they stand some time.)

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Barbara.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: How does thee like London?

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: I knaw not—It do zeem a strange place.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: A strange place?

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—I do think it be.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Thee dost.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: An' zo do I—whereby, dost zee, I'll get out on't as vast as I can—a pretty chace, as the man zaid that rode vifty miles a'ter a wild goose.—London!—an' this be London, the devil take London—come, pack up thy ribbands an' vlappets, an' make thy zel ready.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Neea, zure—you wunt go zo zoon.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Wunt I?—an' I stay in thic town tonight, I'll eat it vor breakvast to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Come, come—don't stand mauxing and dawdling, but make thyzel ready.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: Lord!—Why I a' zeen nothing yet.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No—nor nothing thee zhalt zee—that I promise thee—zo stir thy stumps, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Miss Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!—Mun I go down into 't country again like a vool, an' ha' nothing to zay vor myzel?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Why look thee, Barbara—come along—vor thee have come up like a vool, zo there can be no harm in thy going down like a vool.

div3.head: SCENE I.
div3.stage: A Library in Sir HARRY'S House.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: INDEED, Sir, you have always been the best of masters to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No, Timid, no—I have been a very weak, idle, fellow; and have put it out of my power to be a good master to any one.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday, Sir—don't say so—I am afraid I have been a bad servant—a very bad servant—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Never—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday Sir, you don't know—you don't know—Lackaday, I thought all for the best—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You have only done what I commanded.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: To be sure, Sir—but, lackaday—I wish I durst open my mind to him—I am terrified—he will never believe me innocent.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: My ruin is all my own work—Here, Mr. Timid, take this ring and remember me—It may be the last present I shall ever make you.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Pray don't say so, Sir—I am terrified.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am going to Mr. Osborne's.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: To Mr. Osborne's!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Yes—If you should not see me tomorrow morning—if any accident should happen—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Give the state of my affairs, which I ordered you to draw up, to my uncle, and this picture to Clara, the young lady that is with him.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Sir! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh, nothing, nothing—I'm not very well—I—a slight swimming in my head—that's all—but there is no knowing what may happen.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday, Sir, you terrify me—You talk like a dying man making his will.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No, no,—not so—I have nothing to leave—And as to dying—men must die—live as long as they can, they must all die at last—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Shall I go for Sir Hornet, or your sister, or the young lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No—no young ladies for—Oh!

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday! my heart aches!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am going to Mr. Osborne's, presently.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday—I wish he knew—I'll take the mortgage of the Kentish estate—Mr. Osborne ordered me to bring it—I'll lay it open on Mr. Osborne's table—I hope my dear master will see it—I hope he will discover all.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Heigho—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Dear Sir, don't sigh so—don't look so—tell me what I can do to serve you—to oblige you—to make you happier?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Nothing—nothing—past hope—past cure—quite, quite—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: A thoughtless—profligate—idle—dissipated fellow—Oh my head—my head—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I cannot bear to see him so—I'll hurry to Mr. Osborne's—I'll try if I can yet persuade him to be a true friend—I'll beg, I'll pray, I'll go down on my knees—I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Clara! an angel! a cherub! And what am I? Well, well, it will soon be all over—there will be a sudden stop—a speedy end— (laughing without) So happy—Heaven—Heaven increase your joys!—mine are for ever fled—light laughter, innocent smiles, and social mirth are fled for ever, for ever—Oh folly!—Oh madness!

div3.stage: Enter Sir HORNET, VANDERVELT, and CLARA (laughing.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ay, ay, pray laugh, laugh heartily, I beseech you—I deserve, and I desire no mercy.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It is one of the oddest adventures.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: How the deuce could you mistake that blowzabel, Miss Turnbull, for my turtle?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why true, as you say, friend Van: but that happens to be a blunder which I never did, nor ever could make. I should as soon take myself for a king, or you for a conjuror. I only mistook this lady to be Miss Turnbull, not Miss Turnbull to be this lady.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Mistook Miss Turnbull and this lady, and—I don't understand it.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Be kind enough, Sir Hornet, to explain the matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: You remember, Madam, I had some conversation with you in the rooms at Bath.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Persectly—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: And you could not but perceive how forcibly I was struck with your wit, beauty, and accomplishments.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I recollect you were very polite, Sir, and were pleased to say abundance of obliging things.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Not half so many as I thought, I assure you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Well said, Sir Hornet——My old friend is quite enamoured with you, turtle.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, so I am—though I do not intend to marry the lady.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: My grand object, the thing that, of all others, I have most at heart, is to see my nephew, Sir Harry, happy—As for myself, I feel I am growing old apace, and am almost tired of the farce of life.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Why so, Sir Hornet? I am sure you play your part excellently.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: No, no—I am rolling down hill apace, and as the first steep declivity may precipitate me to the bottom, there are certain affairs I wish to see finished, one of which is the marriage of Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: So the person you asked concerning me, when I went out of the rooms, mistook the question, and thought you meant Miss Turnbull?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p:
So it appears, madam—And I was too much enraptured to stay to rectify mistakes—when I negotiated the affair with 'Squire Turnbull, I studiously avoided an interview with his supposed sister, for fear the business should wear a face of precipitate indelicacy.—And I thought if I could once bring you and Sir Harry together, I would leave the contingent possibilities to love, and the superior good qualities and penetration of the parties,
which I, rationally enough, concluded could not fail to produce the desired effect.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But, Sir Hornet, how did it happen that you did not enquire of me myself who I was?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why faith, madam, I had been so particular with you, and had spoken so freely on the subjects of love and matrimony, that I was afraid, if I made those kind of enquiries, you would mistake the matter, perhaps, and think I wanted to make love to you in my own proper person. Hey, young Van—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Heigho!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh! no, Sir Hornet—I assure you, I had a better opinion of your understanding.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Certainly, had I been capable of such a whim, I should have made myself curs'd ridiculous, Hey, young Van—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Beyound dispute!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Heigho!

div3.stage: Enter TIMID, looking wild and frighted.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Heyday! What's the matter with you, old Lackaday?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I'm terrified—I'm terrified—I'm terrified!—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Terrified!—what's the matter?—Zounds! why don't you speak?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday—I can't—I can't speak.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Make signs then.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I'm a miserable old man—I ran all the way to tell you—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Mr. Osborne!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Mr. Osborne! What of him?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday—Sir Harry!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Heavens!—A duel.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I have put my trust in man, and am deceived—I have lean'd upon a reed, and am fallen—I have seen the shadow of friendship, and—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Curselight on your metaphors; come to facts—What of Osborne? What of Sir Harry? Where are they? What have they done? What are they doing?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Gambling!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I was at Mr. Osborne's when Sir Harry came—I was there with the mortgage of the Kentish estate.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: It was executed this very day—I am a miserable old man—all lost!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Lost!

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday! that's not all—I went into the next room, and heard Sir Harry go to gaming, with a gang of sharpers that were there on purpose—Sir Harry had lost every thing he had in the world—Mr. Osborne has got all—All the mortgages of all his estates—I saw 'em—left 'em all in a box on his table.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Mortgages of all his estates! Perdition!—How did he get them?—How came you to know?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday! I am terrified—I dare not tell—I am an accomplice!—A wicked, innocent, miserable old man.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Damnation! Order the coach there—I'll tear him to atoms—I'll rend him piecemeal—my poor boy—an intolerable villain!—Dear Madam, you don't know what I feel.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Pardon me, Sir Hornet, if you knew my heart, you would not say so—I detest the treachery of Mr. Osborne as much as you do; and, woman as I
am, would risk my life to see it properly punished.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: A smooth tongued, hypocritical villain, that owes his life to my boy.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Dear Sir Hornet, excuse my weakness—I am in the utmost terror—in dread of consequences still more fatal.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday, Sir, so am I—I am terrified—Sir Harry gave me this ring for a remembrance, and bade me deliver this picture to you, Madam—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.stage: (Looks at it, and bursts into tears.)
sp.p: —It is his own—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: He look'd so melancholy, and so furious—He had his pistols.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: His pistols!—Oh for pity's sake, Sir Hornet, let us fly.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Instantly.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I'm a miserable old man.

div3.head: SCENE II.
div3.stage: Sir Harry enters excessively agitated, followed by Osborne, with a brace of pistols he had wrested from him.

sp.speaker: Oshorne.
sp.p: How now, Sir Harry—What is the cause of this sudden phrenzy? Why expose your want of temper and fortitude thus to the company?—You have driven them away—they are all going—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh! horror!

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: If you must wreak vengeance on yourself, let it be a becoming one at least.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Insupportable horror!

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Fie, fie, recover your temper—be, or seem to be a man—What—You knew you were ruined before this event.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh, Osborne! Oh, Melissa! I cannot speak—I cannot utter it—I'm a wretch—a villain—the meanest—the worst of villains—and infamy—eternal infamy is mine.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Why, what have you done?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Ruined you—ruin'd my sister—

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: And branded myself, everlastingly, a villain.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Ruin'd me! ruin'd your sister! which way?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: The money I have lost within—

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Is her's—Is your's.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Mine!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Melissa's—her fortune—She put it into my hand this very day—

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Have compassion on me—give me the pistols, let me at once put an end to my misery and shame.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Thoughtless, weak man! Do you think the momentary pang of death a sufficient punishment for the ruin and distruction you have entailed upon all those who have had the misfortune to love, or to be related to you? Do you think that to DIE, and to forget at once your infamy and crimes, is a compensation for the havoc you have made with the peace and property of those who were dearest to you, who must LIVE to feel the effect of your vices, and bear, unjustly, the reproach of your abandoned conduct—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh torture!

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p:
Was it not enough that you had reduced yourself, from affluence and honour, to contempt and beggary, but you must wantonly, wickedly, sport with what was not your own;
and involve the innocent and unborn in your wretchedness?—Shall not your sister's offspring, whom your intemperance shall have reduced to poverty and misery, detest your memory, and imprecate curses on your name?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh hell!

div3.stage: (Sir Hornet speaks without, and afterwards enters, followed by Clara and Timid.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Where are they? which is the room? So, Mr. Lucifer—Could you decoy your friend to no other place to rob him, but your own house?

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Did you address yourself to me, Sir Hornet.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes, I did, Sir Satan, and if—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Dear Sir, forbear—I alone am the proper object of anger—of vengeance—a wretch—a despised and miserable outcast; and bitterness and despair are deservedly my portion.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: You are a dupe—a poor sascinated fool—you have beheld the serpent's mouth open, have felt the insluence of his poisonous breath, yet stupidly dropt into his ravenous jaws, and sung a requiem to your own destruction.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: You are liberal, Sir, of your epithets and accusations. What do you mean by them?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Horrible impudence! Have you not taken a vile, a rascally advantage of the want of temper in the man, for whom you profest the most perfect friendship? Have you not stripped him of his estate, by the most villainous arts, by plotting with Jews and scoundrels?

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Your talk loud, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Osborne! plotting! the letter then was true!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes, plotting!—He is the principal, the leader of the hellish gang that has been plundering you.

sp.speaker: Osborne
sp.p: Well, Sir!—suppose it—What then?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: What then! Halters!—

sp.speaker: Osborne
sp.p: Why so, Sir!—He has persisted in bringing destruction upon himself, and must suffer the effects of his obstinacy—What crime was there in my receiving what he was resolved to throw away. He had not been a month returned from his travels, before his passion for play made him the jest of every polite sharper in town—They saw there was an estate to be scrambled for, and every one was industrious to obtain a share—After squandering a part of his fortune among these adventurers, he engaged at play with me; and after losing one sum, was never easy till he had lost another—Am I then to be accountable for his folly?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Infernal treachery! Dares he avow it!

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Dare! Yes Sir—I dare.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Righteous heaven! Is there no peculiar, no quick vengeance for ingratitude?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: The deeds, the annuities you have granted, the mortgages you have made, are in his possession—he owns—he has them all—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: He!

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—I.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Madness! remember and beware—remember and tremble, tho' I have no longer the fortune of Sir Harry Portland, I have still Harry's spirit, and dare chastise insolence and perfidy yet—

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: No doubt—The man who is rash enough to risk his estate upon the chance of a die, has generally valour enough to wish to cut the winners throat—Friendship is no protection.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Friendship! Monstrous prostitution! Friendship! Deeds Mr. Osborne are the best proofs
of friendship, and that, preacher will gain but little credit, who is a detected villain, while he is describing the fitness and beauty of moral virtue.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Friendship! Where are the deeds, the mortgages?

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: There they are, Sir— (points to a box) They are mine—the annuities he has granted, and the mortgages he has made are mine—his effects are mine—his houses are mine, his estates are mine, his notes are mine, his ALL is mine; except his poverty and spirit, which, as he says are his own.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Heavens! must I bear this?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh! for ratsbane or hemp—

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Nay more, Sir (to Sir Harry) I was not only aware, but certain of my own superior address, or I had not been weak enough to have risqued any part of my fortune—I have not yet acquired your heroic contempt for riches; as it was, I used, every art to stimulate and incite you to play—took every advantage, studied every trick, improved every lucky chance, and rejoiced at every and all of your losses, 'till I had you totally in my power—I beheld distress accumulating on your head, and was happy at it; remarked the agitation of your mind, and increased it; saw the insirmity of your temper, and aggravated it.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Damnation!—Are you a man?

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Try me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Dare you give me the satisfaction—the revenge of a man?

sp.speaker: Osborne
sp.p:
I'll give it you instantly, Sir— (As Sir Harry offers to go, Osborne seizes his arm, and before he speaks, his countenance changes from assumed anger and contempt, to the most tender and expressive friendship.)
There, there lies your revenge—there is your satisfaction—take them—remember your sormer folly, and be happy—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Astonishment!

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Why do you seem surprized?—my heart is your's, my life is your's—I owe you every thing—A debt which never can be repaid, and never will be forgotten.—When sinking beneath the murderous hand of villainy, it was the benevolent ardor of your soul, it was the intrepid valour of your arm that rescued me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Generous friend!

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: In that box is contained all that I have ever won of you, and almost all you have ever lost—I have become and associate with sharpers to protect you from them, and by sacrificing a little, have preserved the rest. I have worn the mask till it is become too painful, and now gladly cast it off.— (To Sir Hornet and company) If my conduct has yet a dubious appearance—I have a witness that will instantly be credited.
sp.stage: (Goes to the chamber door and calls Melissa; Melissa enters, runs to Sir Harry, and falls upon his neck.)

sp.speaker: Melissa.
sp.p: My brother!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sister! Osborne!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh my heart!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.stage: (after a pause, and endeavouring to restrain his tears)
sp.p: Tol der rol.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday!—I'm a happy old man!—He's a true friend!—he's a true friend!—I'm a happy old man!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Can you too, sister, forgive my folly? You that I have injured so unpardonably?

sp.speaker: Melissa.
sp.p:
Dear brother, you are not so guilty as you suppose—it was a plot upon you; you were
led into it, to shew you what a losing gamester is capable of?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir? (to Osborne) All the mortgages and deeds are there, you say?

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: All, Sir—together with whatever money else has, at any time, been won of him, since I have been concerned in this transaction.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: All in that box?

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I'm a happy old man.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: My dear uncle!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Let me alone—Tol der rol— (Goes up to Osborne, takes his hand, and wipes his own eyes) Will you forgive me, Osborne? Will you? Will you forgive my boy?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Osborne!—I cannot speak—

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Indeed, Mr. Osborne, I don't know how to tell you what I think—Esteem—admiration—veneration—are poor expressions to convey my feelings—I have been mistaken and to blame—I trembled for Sir Harry, I rashly condemned you, and wrote a letter—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Dear Madam, was that letter your's?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: How much obliged am I to you, and to you all.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I am sorry, I was to blame.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p:
Nay, Madam—Nobody was to blame—Angels are actuated by motives like your's, and if they never err, it is because they have commerce with angels only.—And now, dear Harry, suffer me to say one word—Let this transaction be a powerful, an everlasting memento to you.—Remember the blood that has been spilt in the moment of passion and distress, in consequence of indulging in this shocking vice—Remember
the distracted wife, and widow's curse, the orphans tears, the sting of desperation, and the red and impious hand of suicide; despise the folly that made the practice fashionable; oppose its destructive course, and for ever shun, for ever abominate, the detestable vice of gaming.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Professions of resolution, from me, Osborne, come with an ill grace—I am ashamed of my folly—I despis'd, even while I practised it; but the punishment you have inslicted, has been so judicious, so severely generous, I think I can safely say, there is no probability of a relapse.

sp.speaker: Sir hornet.
sp.p: Well, but Harry, turn about—look at this lady—surely you have not forgot Miss Turnbull—have you?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Your Miss Turnbull, Sir, I shall never forget.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh! what you have heard the renowned history of my Bath adventure?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Well, and what say you to—hey my cherub—you told me, you know, you had no aversion to the fellow.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Hornet, is that the part of a confidante?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why, yes, it is—for, as I take it, a confidante is but a kind of a go-between to bring the parties together—And here comes the blooming youth— (Enter Vandervelt) here comes Johannes de Temporibus to second the motion.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: To second what motion, Sir Hornet?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: A hymeneal motion.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Can't tell—who are the candidates?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Harry Portland and Clara Forester.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir Hornet, not so fast!—That lady is my ward.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes, and may, if she pleases, be your wife.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Nay—I—I did not say so, Sir Hornet.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: No, but I did, young Van—but hark you— (takes him aside) Resign all your silly pretensions peaceably, throw your worthies into the fire, and give up the lady to her lover; or you shall be held up, in terrorem, an object of ridicule, to frighten all the dangling, whining, old fools in christendom, who are turned of threescore.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Well, well, speak in a lower key.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: May I be certain of your consent then?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Why, yes—yes—heigho:—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Dear Madam—this worthy old Gentleman, your guardian, most humbly implores you would have pity upon Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Did you say so, papa?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Me! no—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: N—not in those exact words, but something very like it, Turtle—heigho!—

sp.speaker: Melissa.
sp.p: Come, my dear Clara—Let me have the happiness to call you sister—

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Let me intercede, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Pshaw—here is every body interceding, but him that can intercede most to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Forgive me, dearest Clara—My fate is suspended on your lips, and I am so conscious of unworthiness, and so much affected by the fear of a severe sentence, that I have not power to plead for mercy.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Yes—but you have a partial, tender-hearted judge.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ay—"and a wise young judge" too—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Well, well!—I cannot dissemble. A generous heart, a noble mind, are seldom met and seldom merited. When happiness like this presents itself, to reject is not to deserve it.

sp.l: INFORM me, you, at whom he seems to write,
Don't this man's insolence your spleen excite?
Give the beau-monde impertinent advice?
Proscribe VINGT UNE—prohibit box and dice!
Tell YOU of honour, infamy, undoing,
And—impudently preach you out of ruin?
Are cards and dice fit subjects for his fables?—
He'd better write a tragedy on E. O. tables?
And why, with so much rudeness and ill-nature,
'Gainst PRIVATE vice urge acrimonious satire,
Since legal lotteries flourish every year,
And peers and pedlars run the mad career
Of public ruin, in its full extent,
And beggars game—BY ACT OF PARLIAMENT!
Nay, once in seven years, in full perfection,
Is play'd a game more desp'rate, call'd, "ELECTION!"
When each grave senator the cause promotes,
And throws the main with—cogg'd and loaded votes;
When honour, conscience, justice, law, religion,
Are ev'ry one, by turns, the plunder'd pigeon!
But wherefore rail at games in any station?
Life is, itself, a game at calculation,
In which Dame Fortune gains but little thanks,
For each man swears HIS prizes are all blanks.
So when your am'rous lover draws for wife,
And wit and beauty link with him for life,
Tho' twice ten thousand vows of love were paid,
To gain the charming!—dear!—angelic maid!—
Tho' constancy and raptures were the theme!—
Let but possession chace the honey'd dream,
His bouncing passion bursts like bonfire squib,
And wit and beauty form—A CROOKED RIB!
The lordly husband takes a different tone,
When once sweet Miss becomes "bone of his bone!"
The tender epithet, the dying leer,
Are chang'd to—"Damme, Madam, can't you hear?"
For these, poor authors, who their pens employ
To write down pleasures which they can't enjoy,
You, against whom they aim their boldest strokes,
Have too much NONCHALANCE to mind their jokes;
You find them soporifics, quite composing,
For all the while they're preaching, you are dozing.
Our bard, who full of antiquated notions,
Intends to cure the world by scenic potions,
Gravely resolves to set the nation right,
If your applause should crown his hopes to night.
